Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Evolution of Diet Breadth through Ecoimmunology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human commerce and other anthropogenic activities have caused widespread changes in the geographic ranges of species, affecting how species interact within their communities. Since plant-feeding insects represent a large part of Earth's terrestrial biomass, understanding the factors that influence them to change their diets is central to predicting if and how newly organized ecosystems will function. Ecoimmunology is an emerging discipline that highlights the role of the immune system in species interactions and the evolution of life history traits. Although research in plant-insect interactions has long recognized that the range of plant species eaten by insects is shaped not only by characteristics of the plants, but also by enemies such as predators and parasites, the role played by immunological defense in determining dietary breadth is a new area of study. This research explores the hypothesis that resistance to pathogens attained via enhanced immunity can affect the likelihood of incorporating new plant species into insect herbivore diets.

To test this hypothesis, researchers will combine approaches from ecoimmunology, chemical ecology and microbiology, using a model system of four butterfly species, all of which have incorporated the introduced plant, Plantago lanceolata (Plantaginaceae), into their diets. Researchers will assess whether the use of the introduced plant is associated with altered disease risk by quantifying parasitism rates and environmental levels of two common pathogens in different populations of each butterfly species that vary in their use of P. lanceolata. In the laboratory, genetic stock from these populations will be used to compare the immunological response to microbial pathogens and simulated parasitism among caterpillars feeding on P. lanceolata and ancestral host plant species. Researchers will experimentally investigate the interplay between diet, the sequestration of plant chemicals, and the bacteria residing in the insect gut by measuring the immune response when these factors have been manipulated. Finally, they will test whether larval infection history affects which plants are chosen by ovipositing females, or whether shifts to P. lanceolata reflect selection on innate host preference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this project, we sought to understand how defensive chemicals in plants impact the immune system of insects, and in turn how these interactions have impacted the evolution of herbivorous insect diets. To do so, we studied four species of butterfly caterpillars that have recently incorporated an exotic plant into their diet, combining observations from the field and laboratory experiments to test the effects of feeding on different species of plants with varying chemistries. We found that plant chemistry is quite variable between plant species, across the season, and between years, and that this variation is a dominant factor driving the defensive traits of herbivorous insects, impacting both their chemical and immune defenses against predators, parasitoids and pathogens.

To date, this project has increased our understanding of how plant chemistry impacts interactions between herbivorous insects and their natural enemies through changes in the insect immune system. This research not only advanced the emerging field of ecoimmunology, but also brought consideration of the immune system into other fields of study, such as plant-herbivore interactions and the evolution of diet breadth. Our results have been disseminated through numerous peer-review journal articles, 15 professional conference presentations, one honors thesis, one master?s thesis, and in one book chapter. Moreover, 2 postdoctoral research associates, one international visiting postdoctoral associate, and 11 undergraduate students received training in chemistry, field methods, and in laboratory immunological techniques and theory.

In addition to impacting our field of study, our results have also been shared with the general public directly through the development of a museum exhibit, Becoming Butterflies, which opened at the CU Museum of Natural History on April 9, 2016. This exhibit featured information on butterfly and caterpillar biology as well as their defenses against predators, parasitoids and pathogens, and highlighted some of the theory and research in this project. We also participated in numerous public outreach events, including public lectures, family days, and a special evening of moth collecting at the museum. This exhibit continued to impact public audiences when moved to CU South Denver, and eventually the Museum at the University of Nevada Reno. To date, an estimated 70,000 museum visitors have had the opportunity to interact with the exhibit and learn more about interactions between plants, herbivorous insects, and their natural enemies.
